Award.AwardTitle: REU SITE: Research in Consumer Networking Technologies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This funding renews a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the University of Missouri - Columbia. Undergraduate students will engage in summer research involving a variety of interesting and challenging technical issues in consumer networking. Experienced faculty mentors will lead projects in five major research areas including software defined networking, social media computing, social health networking for eldercare, body-area sensing and emotion recognition, and network performance optimization. The students will participate in the faculty mentors' on-going funded research, investigate technically challenging issues, and develop viable solutions and insights. They will have opportunities to present their research results at various venues at the university, national, and international levels. The site will focus on recruiting students from non-PhD granting institutions with particular emphasis on institutions in and around the state of Missouri.

The intellectual merit of the project rests with the leadership an experienced research group with excellent expertise and experience in the research area. The research activities will lead to a better understanding of the multitude of efficiency, performance, reliability, scalability, and security issues and tradeoffs in emerging consumer networking technologies. The approach of integrating future Internet technologies such as Internet-of-Things and software-defined networking in the REU Site will foster the rapid deployment of advanced consumer networking services and applications that are of significance to the economy and quality of life in areas such as social computing and health care.

The broader impacts include providing a unique opportunity for undergraduate students with limited research opportunities to experience research in the interdisciplinary areas of consumer networking. With an already established recruitment network, the project team plans to reach the targeted students and encourage applications from women engineers and under-represented minorities as well as students from predominantly undergraduate institutions. The program should be of great interest to undergraduate students due to its close interaction between daily life and exciting consumer networking technologies. The research experiences offer students insight into the requirements of advanced degrees by closely working with faculty mentors and graduate students, and may lead to students ultimately pursuing advanced degrees and fulfilling careers in science and engineering. The professional evaluation by an external assessment specialist should contribute to educational research on effective structures for involving undergraduates in research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This REU site is in the field of Consumer Networking Technologies and investigates important issues related to software-defined networking, social media computing, social health networking for eldercare, body-area sensing and emotion recognition, and network performance optimization. Ten students engaged in a 10-week summer program every year for three years at the University of Missouri – Columbia (MU). More than half of the participants were under-represented minority students and from universities with limited research opportunities. This program provided unique opportunities for undergraduate students to experience training and research in the consumer networking field.

The program included a 1-week short course, multiple additional short lectures on in-depth technical knowledge and technical writing and presentation skills, about 9-week group research on selected projects that were carefully designed and well aligned with the faculty mentors’ on-going research, weekly program seminars, multiple individual project meetings per week, interim progress reports, a final research paper, and a final presentation. Students participated in two field trips each year, one at the University of Missouri’s Data Center and the other to visit and speak with students in the Columbia Public School district’s summer school program. 

In collaboration with the MU Office of Undergraduate Research, the REU site program participated in a serial of campus-wide undergraduate research activities, including Tuesday/Thursday evening seminars on various topics for 8 weeks, Intern - Mentor BBQ, and Farewell Picnic. The REU students received a weekly newsletter via email to help keep them apprised of these activities. At the end of the 10-week summer program, together with other summer research programs on the MU campus, the students participated in a recognition ceremony, and presented their posters in the Summer Undergraduate Research and Creative Achievements Forum coordinated by the MU Office of Undergraduate Research.

At this REU Site, students developed new research, communication, and team-working skills in ongoing research projects of the faculty mentors by investigating, implementing, and testing various solutions to technical challenges. The research activity allowed the students to obtain a better understanding of the technical issues, performance, and trade-offs in consumer networking. The program exposed the students to collaborative research environments, fostered their enthusiasm for science and engineering, and developed their technical and communication skills needed for pursuing advanced degrees in research. All REU students participated and presented their posters at the MU Summer Undergraduate Research and Creative Achievements Forum. The results of eight projects have been accepted or published by international conferences.  Project information, including final presentations and posters, are available at the MU REU Site website: http://reu.rnet.missouri.edu.

The REU site has provided undergraduate students with the opportunity to research on a variety of interesting technical issues in the emerging field of consumer networking. The demand for networked consumer systems and devices is large and growing. At home, in vehicles, at work, or at play, consumers want reliable and secure networking for the systems and devices that they rely on for entertainment, information, and communications.   Consumer networks are becoming a significant information source and sink.  However, users often do not have the technical skills or training to build and maintain stable and secure networks.  This presents the challenge of developing technologies that are easy to use, highly available, and secure but do not require specific skills and training to install and maintain.   This REU site helped attracting, educating and training our next generation of computing and networking researchers.

The PIs and other faculty mentors have been actively engaged in addressing major challenges in consumer networking areas. The REU projects were well aligned with the PIs and faculty mentors' on-going research. The students have helped investigate some of the technical issues, research and test viable solutions during the 10-week summer session. The systems developed by the students have become part of the platforms for on-going research in the PIs and faculty mentors' research group.   The students' works have resulted in many presentations in a campus-wide forum, and multiple papers accepted by international conferences. More importantly, this 10-week summer program has exposed the students to the whole life cycle of collaborative research, making them better prepared for pursuing advanced degrees or innovative research and development.

This program provided unique opportunities and improved the performance, skills, or attitudes of REU students, especially members of underrepresented groups and those from non-research-intensive universities, in researching and solving real-world technical problems. The student projects are sufficiently sophisticated and state-of-the-art, and hence permit the students to publish and present the results in the form of short/full papers or posters in technical conferences in the specific research areas.
